org.simplity.kernel.dt

Class DataType

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.simplity.kernel.dt.DataType
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Component
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BooleanDataType, DateDataType, NumericDataType, TextDataType

    public abstract class DataType
extends Object
implements Component
    DataType describes the constraints on the range of values that a data-element/field can have
    Author:
    simplity.org

      • getSimpleName

        public String getSimpleName()
        Specified by:
        getSimpleName in interface Component
        Returns:
        simple name, with no prefix (module). Component name is unique within a module, but may not be across modules. Hence a moduleName is to be used to refer to a components

      • getQualifiedName

        public String getQualifiedName()
        Specified by:
        getQualifiedName in interface Component
        Returns:
        qualified name. Dotted if you use modules and sub-modules. Similar to java class and package notation.

      • getReady

        public void getReady()
        Description copied from interface: Component
        Components may have to set-up their shops after loading the attributes. Typically ensuring referential integrity, caching etc.. In case of components having sub-components, it is generally a good idea to have setUp() only for the parent component, from where you may trigger set-up of child components
        Specified by:
        getReady in interface Component

      • getSqlType

        public String getSqlType()
        returns the string that represents the data type to be used in create SQL for a column of this type
        Returns:
        sql type of this data type

      • parseValue

        public final Value parseValue(String textValue)
        parse supplied text and return parsed value. we decided against throwing an exception on error. we return null silently instead. We recommend that you handle null in your code, and send only non-null text for parsing. That way the code is more readable/maintainable. However, for completeness,if you pass null as textValue, we return a valid value object with null as its value.
        Parameters:
        textValue - text to be parsed. null implies that the caller wants a Value object with null-value in it.
        Returns:
        parsed value, null in case of any error.

      • getValueType

        public abstract ValueType getValueType()
        Convenient method to get the actual type of the subclass
        Returns:
        value type

      • validateValue

        public abstract Value validateValue(Value value)
        validate value as per this data type definition, and return valid value. It is important to note that the returned value could be different from supplied value because of data-type specific approximations, like rounding-off and knocking-off time.
        Parameters:
        value - to be validated
        Returns:
        null if value is invalid. Value (possibly modified as per data-type rules) if it is valid.

      • getMaxLength

        public abstract int getMaxLength()
        maximum length of this value.
        Returns:
        maximum number of characters

      • getScale

        public int getScale()
        Returns:
        0 for non-numeric data types, and number of positions after decimal point for number
